TEXT: CARDINAL . ORG At the time of the events giving rise to this case , Mr. PERSON , a NORP national born in DATE , was a student and resident in GPE .

CARDINAL . ORG During refresher courses ( PERSON ) organised in DATE and DATE as part of ordinary military obligations , he was subjected to CARDINAL and CARDINAL days’ strict arrest for refusing to comply with Article CARDINAL bis of the service regulations , relating to hair - cuts .

CARDINAL . ORG Shortly before DATE refresher course , the applicant received a registered letter from his unit commander instructing him to report for the course with a regulation hair - cut . He nevertheless presented himself on CARDINAL DATE with his hair longer than authorised and refused to obey the officer ’s verbal order to have it cut .

CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , ORG ( auditeur militaire ) drew up a " bill of indictment " ( PERSON ) against Mr. PERSON , charging him with repeated insubordination and , subsidiarily , failure to observe service regulations ( Articles CARDINAL and DATE of LAW ) .
CARDINAL . ORG On DATE , at the close of a public hearing , ORG no . CARDINAL delivered in public a judgment sentencing the applicant to CARDINAL days’ imprisonment for the CARDINAL offences .

Mr. PERSON ’s defence counsel had unsuccessfully requested ORG to decline jurisdiction on the ground that it lacked the independence and impartiality required by LAW ; he had also applied , in vain , for a supplementary enquiry into the futility , or indeed abusive nature , of the regulations on hair - cuts .
A copy of the decision was sent to the applicant on DATE .

CARDINAL . ORG Having been duly informed by the grand juge ( President of ORG ) that he could appeal on points of law within TIME from delivery of the judgment , Mr. PERSON had immediately given notice of appeal to the Registrar ( section CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of ORG of DATE - " LAW " ) .

On DATE , within the prescribed period of DATE from service of the judgment , the applicant filed a memorial containing a " final " statement ( section CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of LAW ) of his grounds of appeal .

He submitted that the decision appealed against had infringed the law ( section CARDINAL para . CARDINAL , no . CARDINAL , of LAW ) by applying regulations that were incompatible with LAW article CARDINAL) of the LAW ; that ORG had not been composed in the manner prescribed by law ( ibid . , no . CARDINAL ) , CARDINAL of the CARDINAL judges being substitutes for the ordinary judges and the grand juge having been appointed by ORG ( auditeur en chef ) ; that ORG had erred in not declining jurisdiction to hear the case on the merits ( ibid . , no . CARDINAL ) , since the military courts were not tribunals within the meaning of LAW ) ; and that the refusal to order a supplementary enquiry had prejudiced the defence on decisive points ( ibid . , no . CARDINAL ) concerning the application of LAW article CARDINAL) and in particular paragraph CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL - CARDINAL ) thereof .

Mr. PERSON also drew the attention of ORG to the fact that it was not consonant with LAW ) to conduct proceedings entirely in writing ; he therefore requested it to hold CARDINAL hearing and to pronounce its judgment publicly .

CARDINAL . ORG The grand juge transmitted the appeal to ORG , in his capacity as respondent ; the latter was entitled to " submit his observations " within DATE ( section CARDINAL para . CARDINAL of LAW ) , but chose not to do so .
The grand juge afterwards sent the appeal and the papers in the case , without appending " his report on the matters in dispute " ( ibid . ) , to the Chief Military Prosecutor .

The latter forwarded the documents to ORG . He could himself have filed observations if he had thought fit , but - like ORG and the grand juge - he confined himself to submitting that the appeal should be dismissed .

CARDINAL . ORG The President of ORG requested a judge whom he had designated from amongst his colleagues to draft a report containing a reasoned proposal . This document was circulated , together with the papers in the case , amongst the other members . On DATE , ORG deliberated on the matter in camera and dismissed the appeal . It thus did not rule on the merits of the case ; according to the provisions then in force ( section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act ) , it could have done so only if the judgment had been quashed and the sole ground for the quashing had been misapplication of the law . This power ORG no longer enjoys ( see paragraph CARDINAL below ) .

The operative provisions of the judgment were immediately served on Mr. PERSON in writing . He received the full text on DATE ( section CARDINAL of the CARDINAL Act ) . The reasons covered CARDINAL pages and concerned mainly Mr. PERSON ’s submissions as to the incompatibility of the DATE Act with Articles CARDINAL and CARDINAL ( article CARDINAL , article CARDINAL) of the LAW . As to the composition of ORG , the judgment stated that the substitute judges had the same legal status as the ordinary judges , and that ORG had not infringed the law by appointing the grand juge - who had the status of an ordinary judge - to sit on the case , the ordinary president being unable to take part as he had had to deal with the matter at a previous stage as Military Prosecutor .

CARDINAL . ORG At the time of the facts giving rise to the present case , military criminal procedure was governed by LAW ( see paragraph CARDINAL above ) . As regards the public character of the proceedings , this LAW drew a distinction according to the level of the court concerned .
ORG , which heard military - law cases at first instance , were required to give their decisions after holding public hearings and to pronounce their judgments in open court .

On the other hand , proceedings before ORG were conducted entirely in writing and its judgments were not delivered in public . Concerning the latter point , section CARDINAL of the Act laid down merely that " an extract " of the judgment had to be communicated to ORG , the accused and the grand juge .
CARDINAL . ORG LAW was repealed by ORG of DATE ( " LAW " ) , which entered into force on DATE .
The existing system was maintained for proceedings before ORG , and was extended to ORG which were set up by the same statute .

As regards ORG , LAW provides that " There shall be no oral hearings " ( section CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ) . The LAW did , however , make CARDINAL innovations : in future , ORG was to deliver judgment in open court ( sections CARDINAL para . CARDINAL and CARDINAL para . CARDINAL ) and could in no circumstances itself rule on the merits of the case .

CARDINAL . ORG As was also the case in the past , the judgments of ORG are collected together DATE in a provisional form ( roneotyped ) . Anyone who can establish an interest may consult or obtain a copy of the full text on application to ORG or the military court registries .
If judgments contain features that are novel or of importance for the interpretation of the law , they are subsequently published in printed form .
